The beer selection is not up to my snobbery, but whatevs, they have Racer 5 and that'll do.  The service is sometimes really sub par and sometimes decent, but always only attractive blonde ladies.
author: Bobby S.

description:
My roasted vegetable hash was decent and enormous. I'd ordered a side of squash and had to split both of them with my travel companion. Bloody Mary was spicy and strong, although the garnishes were more minimal than I'd prefer (one onion, one olive, one spicy green bean). Irish Coffee was the best part of the meal... strong and delicious. 

Genuinely friendly service and comfy booths.
author: Kimberley D.

description:
Used to be much better than it is today. Menu hasn't changed, but the bar itself and its patrons have. Maybe it's a product of the ever evolving Mission. This used to be a great friendly neighborhood spot. Now it's more of a sports bar than anything else. Which isn't all bad if you want to watch a game, except its more of a shitty frat-boy type sports bar with lots of high fives and chest pumps. 

In its defense, great beer selection and the food is pretty good for bar food. Strangely, they have the best chicken wings in the Mission and the soda bread is the shit!
author: Doug H.

description: Great neighborhood bar! Go there to catch a game, grab a bite to eat, or just meet a friend for a drink.  A large & tasty menu, with a hard-working and gifted kitchen staff to back it up. Lovely ladies are always behind the bar and working the floor. The bar back Gilberto is the hardest-working man I've ever met.  And the bouncer/doorman Steve is the consummate professional who does a bang-up job keeping the pub and its patrons safe and secure.  What's not to love about this place?
author: Noah Plays Bass M.

description:
This is one of my reliable favorites. The food & drinks, service, and the sense of character are all pretty sound.

You're going to find great breakfast here, the serious kind of breakfasts that leave you full til supper. They have mostly American and the popular Irish dishes. Their bloody marys are yummy with just enough spice while the mimosas are hit or miss pending on your bartender. 

I like to come here on Sundays and watch Steeler games with the regulars. So much football going on here it's almost overwhelming in the thank-goodness-it's-football-season way. Wear your gear, represent and enjoy the company.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Outstanding service especially the nights that the cute brunette and redhead work together. They treat everybody in the bar like kings and queens.
Food is outstanding for pub grub.
Of note: I lost my fanny pack at the bar last week - was sure I'd never get it back, but lo and behold, the girls saved it for me behind the bar. I'm a regular customer now for sure!
author: David L.

description:
One of my favorite bars in San Francisco.  
Warm, engaging (HOT!) bartenders and waitresses
Excellent food
Great music, energetic atmosphere
TVs, which gives it a sort of sports bar feel 

My one complaint, however, and this has little to do with the establishment itself, are all of the drooling, limp-dicked, middle-aged men who claim the bar stools as their own, slowly sipping away on Corona bottles all fucking night long in hopes that patience and perseverance will beget their dreams of romantic dalliances with the servers.  This makes it difficult to order a drink.  

Whatev.
author: Michael L.

description:
Super Bad service merits the low review.  I can work with aloof service people; usually I avoid them. But when I leave cash + credit for a split tab, I expect the cash would go towards the tab and not in someone's pocket.  It doesn't take a rocket scientist to know that when someone leaves 1/2 the amount in cash it's suppose to go towards the bill, especially when its a group of 5 people.
I have been to the Phoenix enough times where I'd expect the bartendresses to greet me with, "hi, how are you?" not decide to sneak in a crazy fat tip... and then get all huffy when we pointed it out to them.  
So if you do go to The Phoenix, stay sober enough to do the math; otherwise, hit a better bar you can feel good about. There are tons of better options in the Mission.
author: Micaela H.

description: Apart from laughing with Justine H. about a cowgirl and the gay pansy boy (no, seriously, he was gay) who asked his friend to approach Justine for him, I don't remember much about this place. However, Jason C. said I was here, and rittle Justine mentioned my name in her review of this place, so I must have been here. I can only deduce from this confusion that I was having way too much fun. Two thumbs up for being a wastey face.
author: Suany W.

description:
It can't get any more pubby than this Irish bar - The Phoenix. This is definitely the place to be after dinner, to get a few drinks, hang out and drop a few dollars to make the jukebox play your fave jams.

Came here on a Saturday night with friends, and it was packed. People were friendly, and overall altmosphere was good. I also noticed that they had a menu for happy hour! Next time, I would love to visit and give their happy hour food offerings a shot.

Until then, if you haven't been here, you should definately check it out.
author: Laughlin S.

description: This is a bar that only serves food to feed the over served in a setting that has very little group seating.  And from the smell I gather that the amateur patrons cannot keep down their liquor or their food.  I don't quite see it as a gathering place for Irish culture, but just drinking culture in general. and any excuse - like St. Patricks Day - to dress up in green plastic crap and get stupid wasted at a neighborhood bar.
author: Russell C.

description:
The Phoenix is a great place.  It is my local, local and there are my great things about it that I'll divide in groupings:

Food-
Food is actually pretty good for bar food.  Should have the spicy wings (best in the City in my opinion) at least once.  Potato nachos sounds like a weird concept but they are very tasty here.  The Chipotle burger is the burger they have there.  They give you 2 big slices of chicken it comes w/ caramelized onions and mushrooms!!  For dinner entrees have the Chicken Pot Pie, chicken is really well made and the pie is so good and creamy.  My favorite is the breakfast.  You should get the Huevos Valencianos w/ Sausage (has avocado, salsa, eggs, beans and good tortillas), Phoenix Scramble is always a safe call and my personal fav is the Skirt Steak w/ eggs & potatoes (it is a special on weekends so look out for it!) which has caramelized onions, mushrooms and a yummy sauce on top.  Don't expect anything fancy w/ the food, just solid good bar food at decent prices.

Drinks-
Never have mixed drinks here to be honest but the Bloody Mary's are extremely popular w/ patrons, it is a must to try once.  Beers are not too expensive but they stopped serving Carlsberg which is a bummer.  Freshly squeezed OJ on weekends is always a good call.  Also try the Irish Coffees but good whiskey pls.  

People-
The bartenders and servers are very nice.  Never had a bad experience w/ them.  The owner usually hires pretty chill girls as bartenders/waitresses (sorry ladies no eye candy for you).   They are all very nice and if you sit at the bar you can easily strike up a nice convo.  sadly there is always big turnover but they always seem to hire cool ppl.

Football/sports-
They have about 8 or 9 flat screen, HD TVs which are great for sports.  Place has become an absolute mad house on Sundays.  Get there early if you want a seat to watch the games.  If you get a good seat in the back you can watch like 4 to 5 games at once!  As long as you POLITELY ask the waitress to put your game on she'll do.  Just don't be rude to them and yell out stuff.  If you get there late, it will be standing room only.  For the Euro Cup finals, Champions League final or World Cup of course the place gets REALLY packed!!  As in people over flowing to the sidewalks trying to catch  glimpse of the game.  Good spot for Giants games esp now that they won it all..surprise, surprise...

Atmosphere-
They have a bunch of Irish posters, pictures, paraphernalia all around the bar.  I've struck a bunch of interesting conversations w/ random strangers there.  It's nice and relaxed on the mornings (expect for Football of course) and at nights it becomes a good crowd/scene.  Folks that frequent the place are pretty cool too.  It'll never be a lounge or club (i hope!) but it's still great to go out to on Fri/Sat night.  

Best advice is to sit at the bar.  Met some pretty nice/interesting folks in the 4+ years i've been coming here.  place attracts way chill people.  check it out!
author: Ivan M.

description:
Happy Hour! (ends at 7?)

This is soooo getting added to my list

$1 Garlic Fries (****)
$3 Fish Tacos (***)
$3 Speakeasy/IPA/Hef (****)
$4 Fried Potato thing (****)
$2 Quesadilla (****)
$3 Buffalo Wings (****)
$2 Onion Rings (****)

And how shall I say more.  Although I've noticed that they sure enjoy using them black beans on anything and everything.  The quesadilla was good and to my surprise, it had the beans which made it filling too.  Just between three of us, we were able to embarass ourselves by taking over the entire end of the bar while other people looked in amazement of these 3 asians and 20 dishes laid out.  

And to be honest, we didn't finish everything, although we got close, as our 4th friend came by late in the game and performed an amazing cleanup.  

They've also got a sit down area and plenty of TVs for any major sporting events.  We watched the Laker vs Magic game 1 here.  The crowd was cool, and I saw three games going on at once while that happened, MLB, NBA, and NHL.  I see many future visits back here.
author: Vincent K.

description:
I may have found a new brunch place.  My fish & chips were excellent, and Wifey loved her corned beef sandwich.  Plus, a pint of Bass helps everything taste better.  The service was friendly and fast and didn't hover.  We got a table immediately at about 1:00.  The bathroom is a bit of a disaster, but it reminds you that this is really a bar, not so much a restaurant.  [But, seriously, the back portion of this place is huge.  They could clearly give up 50 square feet, to add 25 square feet to each of the two bathrooms, and no one would even notice.]

Plus, it's a mere stumble from my place.  [Stalker/Contract Killer Note 8.]
author: Ben P.

description: Good cocktails, ok food, friendly service. Fun for game days.
author: Vicki L.

description: Boddington's and chicken wings. Happy hour specials are fab. Service is awesome. In a neighborhood in flux that's become overrun with reclaimed wood and gray oak, the Phoenix is a bright spot of timeless pub deliciousness.
author: David C.

description: Came in here for a few pints. The ambiance was fine, drinks were reasonable - nothing special, nothing wrong with the place, A-OK all around. From reading the other reviews, it might take ordering some food or mixed drinks to get the full experience. I'd be willing to check it out again.
author: Rob R.

description:
Wow...cute boys actually come here ladies.  But they have no game.  Case in point.  Boy wants to talk to me.  Boy sends his female friend to tell me that he wants to talk to me.  I think this is funny since this isn't first grade.  I would have perhaps let him buy me a drink if Suan W. hadn't pointed out that he was wearing khakis and a plaid shirt.  So she insulted him and I had to decline the "talking invite" since I am a little older than a first grader.  The poor boy was very upset and stormed off in a huff.  Wow, I thought I was sensy.  His friends were really cool though.  

This bar has sports on for the boys (and girls). The music, however, is barely audible.  Fun, fun pub.  We ended up staying here for almost the whole night, which is very rare for my crew.
author: Justine D.

description:
It has really been a while since I saw the sun shine in SF...i know, i know. Mark Twain said that the coldest days he had are during summertime in SF but when its summer you expect at least a week or two to get a high temperature.

Anyway, this has been the coldest summer ever historically that one they were claiming, i have only been in SF for 8 years so I really wouldnt know and besides I only get a taste of summer here towards the end of summer almost fall...yes the Indian summer.

Yesterday we were finally blessed with warm weather, and the "in" place to be when the sun is out is where else but my hood....the mission.

TB has been running a lot of errands like always so we never really planned on doing anything yesterday. When he was done he called and invited me for a bike ride and yesterday was a perfect day. We have been teasing and hinting for a week now about chugging a really nice cool mojito so I told him maybe we can grab this cold drink at a nearby bar, and again you have to give it to my dude for always knowing where to take me thats for sure.

Since we have been feening for the Mojito that's the first thing we ordered and the bartender said they dont have mint...like the previous tuesday that we are feening for chicharong bulaklak this was just one of those blessings in disguise...true enough we decided to get a Margarita...and this is one of the coolest good tasting Margarita I had...and its on the rocks...I would come back here  just for this. TB ordered his hef and buffalo wings...Giants was playing and exploded with 5 scores in the first meeting what more can you ask for?

The bar has a homey feel, the bartender was pleasant.

I will definitely ask him to come back here.
author: Malou C.

description: A-typical Irish style pub. Occasionally I come in here to grab a glass of Guinness. That's about it.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Reasonably priced for the city: we got 1 beer and 2 well drinks for $16.  The well drinks are so/so, on the weak side, so I ordered a HangerOne Mandarin Lemon Drop (standard lemon drop sub the vodka) & it was tasty!  Followed by an equally tasty H1 Kaffir Gimlet (gimlet sub the vodka). {end of hangar one plug}
Good experience overall, I'd come back here to grab a drink & chat with friends.
author: Sally L.

description: Meh.  Blonde bartender had a resting bitch face or maybe just a bad night.
author: Erika P.

description:
Though I generally know that this is the place to watch soccer matches, I wasn't sure if it would be lively enough to watch Joga Bonito (Brasilian Soccer Team), as they played North Korea the other day..

There I sat, initially the only person wearing my Colombian soccer jersey to show support for my neighbors, (Hey!! Atleast it was yellow!!)

Bit by bit, yellow jerseys bearing names like "KaKa", Robinho, and Maicon started filtering in until the normally Irish bar was alive with timbaleiros beating their drums to "Na Canço de Samba"....

Any minute I was expecting someone to bust out doing capoeira or something.

So, for the upcoming World Cup match Sunday 20 June 2010, this is the place to through back a few pints, or irish coffees, and enjoy the sounds of something other than the constant drone of vuvuzela horns.

Obrigado.....
author: Miguel O.

description:
The weather recently hit 90 degrees in SF....... I know, right? San Francisco at 90 degrees?  
"Fuckin-A ! Dunk me in a tankard of cool suds!"  My mouth cried out.

So the Sunday mission was to head to the Mission and find a great bar that had a plenty of cold beers on tap in frosty glasses. Well ventilated seating area was the secondary required criteria. We walked down Valencia and the Phoenix beconed. The bay window seats were open and the bar wasn't to rowdy-crowdy.  In we went and sat down and started an afternoon of kick-ass DRANKIN' ! 

Times were good, the cocktail waitress was on, and hoegardeen was ice cold. We stayed from 4PM to 8PM and headed out for a drunk muchie satisfiying dinner !
author: Mark B.

description:
Aah, the Phoenix. Despite being married to a true Irishman, we 've never been to this pub at night. Instead, it's one of the spots in our rounds for a decent bloody mary on a Sunday monring (or afternoon). 

I thought I was old enough to be past caring about fashion, or the lack thereof. However, now that we live in a little enclave outside the city, when we drove past our intended pub because it was closed on a Sunday afternoon (gasp!) and found ourselves smack in the middle of hipsterville (ie Valencia and 19th St.) I couldn't help feeling kind of John McCain-ish in my Sunday sneakers and light-colored jeans. Feeling out of place at 31 is way less horrible than at 13, though. 

This bar is flush with Irish Herald papers, a necessity, and the bloody marys were awesome: oddly thick, but delicious, just wait for the ice to melt and thin it down. Also comes with a cocktail onion and two olives: YUM!
author: kelly m.

description: Potato wedges were super rad and that's about all the place had going for it. Service was super slow--waitress was unapologetic, and our table left frustrated and thirsty. Only when we asked for the check did our drinks finally arrive. With endless better options to spend a Monday night in the Mission, we won't be back.
author: Sarah I.

description:
Phoenix is one of my favorite HH spots, and it's reallyreallyreally close to my place so I'm always pulling for it when the coworkers are deciding where to go on a Friday night.  Happy Hour specials go til 7 and they are amazing.  The last time I went with a girlfriend we got a Hoegarden, Boddington, irish nachos, and garlic fries for like $13.  Whaaaaaat.  But srsly, their Irish nachos are no joke.  Can't come here and not get them.

My only complaint was that we were sitting at the tables by the windows which were open, and a guy was standing there smoking.  We asked him if he could move to the other side (nicely, of course!) and he chose to be a dick about it.  C'mon srsly?  But it wasn't the Phoenix's fault, so I won't fault them for it.  But if you come here, please don't douche it up for the rest of us.
author: Christie C.

description: Wife and I tried the place out during happy hour and had a good experience. I'm a big fan of casual pubs and friendly bartenders/wait staff and that's exactly what we got here. It was quite full at happy hour and the bartenders were courteous and amicable. The portions (spicy potato wedges and 1/2 fish and chips) were absolutely massive! It could do with a slightly better beer selection on tap but that's being too picky. A great place for a regular hangout and great value for money. I'm a fan!
author: Ash T.

description: Josie and I came here after seeing a private showing of some independent film about something...  No complaints since I love grimy Irish bars.
author: Suz L.

description: WAY understaffed on a Sunday afternoon.  I waited at the bar for 20 minutes.. NOTHING.  Gave up and left.
author: David H.

description:
I rolled in here after the SF Street Food Festival and enjoyed the following, in order:

1) an attentive and attractive waitress  
2) round after round of Guiness (some with clovers) and whiskey 
3) several plates delicious hot wings 
4) 49ers v Raiders and Giants v Colorado
5) a cigarette with a hottie outside
6) credit card payment

The point was, all my needs were satisfied, I had a great time, and will be coming back for sure.
author: Dylan ..

description: It's really frikkin' loud, the wait staff are stroppy, the mens room is a state, and then there's the bouncer. He won't even look up until someone has walked halfway into the bar, then jerks upright and hauls them back for an ID check. What's with that? You can do slacker, you can do proactive, but you can't really do them both at the same time.
author: R O.

description:
The Phoenix has a very interesting mix of elements that I enjoy every time I'm there. Beer, good food, nice TVs and hot waitresses... 

do I need to explain more?

Their Chicken Chipotle sandwich is really good together with the Apple and goat cheese salad.
author: Juan Camilo R.

description: I trust Irish Pubs. When I don't know where to go I can always count on an Irish pub to have great beer selections, decent prices, and a good social atmosphere. Went here during Litquake and it was a good kind of busy in a great location. It would be the perfect place to watch football and drink all day without racking up too big of a tab.
author: Jenny W.

description: The mission isn't much for sports bars, and not that the Phoenix is JUST a sports bar, but it IS a great spot to catch a game or grab a booth and catch up with friends over some pub grub. Lively spot, it's a favorite of mine. Not sure if this is PC but the wait staff also seems to consist primarily of lovely ladies... If you're into that :-)
author: Steve S.

description: I've been a patron of the Phoenix for a few years now... The appeal of their menu always draws me in. The mediocre food and shoddy service always leave me bummed. I will say the chicken wings are bomb, perhaps even some of the best in San Francisco (does that really say anything?). Happy hour is solid with good drink prices and super good appetizers. However the vibe is consistently disappointing. I feel as if I tasted my way through a considerable amount of the menu, it's just really hit or miss. I'm bummed because I really want to like this place. Every three months or so I'll say to myself maybe this time will be different... Unfortunately I end up with a big fat plate of lamesauce :(
author: Daniel C.

description: Even at 9:30am on a Sunday, it can be tough to find a good brunch spot in the Mission that doesn't have a crazy wait.  My friend and I stumbled in here and joined the lone other patron who was slinging back mixed drinks before the 10am threshold.  We chose some breakfast grub instead.  I assume both of us had had far too much to drink the night before, so we eschewed beer, despite the sizeable selection.  He chose pancakes or waffles.  No, pancakes.  I had some and wasn't overwhelmed, but wasn't underwhelmed.  Pretty solid whelming.  My breakfast, however, was a mountain of a meal.  A serpentine gaelic steak was the centerpiece.  It looked like a crispy piece of shit to be honest, but damn, did it taste heavenly.  I liked how under the outer fried coating it was all real steak underneath.  Not quite a medium in juiciness, but still tender.  The house potatoes were golden brown and perfect conduits for ketchup.  I don't remember my eggs so well and I was sadden by the lack of biscuits (toast was included).  All in all, the meal was tasty going down and held my stomach in check until dinner.  Solid investment.  I'd only complain about the menus inconsistency in terms of descriptions.  Not everything is in parallel construction or clear as to what you actually get with your order.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
if you don't fall in love with the brazilian bartender, you are a fool!

the drinks will sneak up on you, the guys working the door are hella cool and chill.  the staff is all cool and chill. the bar itself is, well not entirely my scene (i also arrived solo and was partying solo). 

I would definitely return as I become more familiar with the city and have more friends to invite out!
author: Tom L.

description:
Now this is a great Irish pub! It's not quite as great as Beckett's in Berkeley but it's better than The Chieftain in SOMA. Still, you can't go wrong with any of those three.

The Phoenix is one of the best non-Mexican places to eat in the Mission. It is almost like someone opening up an "El Farolito" right in the middle of Dublin, except it's completely different. What? Exactly. 

Anyway, on to the food. The portions are gigantic. I've had the Phoenix Burger, the Bangers & Mash and the Baked Mac & Cheese. All were delicious and well worth the price (usually more than $10 per plate). The environment is fun and you have to love the fact you are surrounded by big televisions all with sporting events on.

In summation, Bangers & Mash + sports on big screen televisions = victory.
author: Lupe P.

description:
Breakfast here was AWESOME!
No lines, good food and great friends = wonderful brunch!

Nitya and I ordered the whole wheat pancakes with fruit.  Instead of the sausage, we opted for potatoes.  They were like french fries!  I ate all of them.  The pancakes were good too, but super filling because they were a little dense.  Mia ordered the boxty, which was poached eggs and bacon on top of a potato pancake, covered in hollandaise.  The seasonings were really good, but I agreed with her that the dish would have been better if they put soda bread as the bottom layer instead of the potato pancake.  Speaking of which, the waitress brought out a basket of the soda bread when we sat down and it was so good with butter and honey.  Easy parking and friendly servers makes this place worthy of a return trip.  I can't wait to try their regular menu.
author: Lynnie P.

description:
Stopped here for a drink and a late night dinner; complimentary Irish soda bread was really REALLY good. I ordered the roasted pork loin while my friend got the shepherd's pie - portions were large and the food delicious!

Magner's on tap - yay!

They were replaying the world cup match from earlier that day at 10 o'clock at night. Nice.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Casual, friendly, Irish, beer before noon. Six of my favorite words right there.

The Guinness is poured with wait time and precision and the food isn't bad. The Irish nachos (fries with black beans, cheese, and sour cream) are excellent, in fact. 

You know it's good if real Irish people are inside (on both sides of the bar).
author: Donna Z.

description: I'm sad to say that I don't really remember being here.  I came in for a drink after barhopping already.  And that's all I remember, stopping by, nothing stands out.  I'm not even sure if a staff member ever came to our table.  I may go again if I'm in the area, but with so many other options, I may not.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Have been back several times and thougt I'd add that their Shepherd's pie is delish and you can actually split one order in two when ordering and it is plenty for both of you.

Also, if you can find a seat closer to the door it is much more comfortable temperature-wise.  The back is cool, but gets steamy really quickly.  Still a great spot!
author: Greg R.

description: There's never a wait for brunch and their waffles are impressive. The rest of the time, beers are $6 regardless of what you order and service is sometimes spotty. That said, if you just want a table in a clean place on the Valencia strip, this bar's for you.
author: Megan G.

description:
Wow, I was already gonna give this place a great review, but after Yelping them and seeing that the actual name of this place is The Phoenix Bar & Irish Gathering House, as opposed to just The Phoenix, well shit howdy, you just went up a star!!

So last night, my co-workers and I were craving something a little less civilized than the Grappa tasting we had just come from. My vote was on Buffalo Wings, because really, who doesn't crave a little deep fried, spicy lovin after some culturetastical libations?

And so we Yelp Mobiled "Buffalo Wings" and a few places came up, but none of them were really rocking our socks, so my boy Michael suggested just getting some "Irish Gathering" food...actually he said, "Pub" food but that was clearly the wrong terminology for this place...at The Phoenix. So we hopped on the BART and went down to this place.

When we walked in we spotted a few seats at the bar between an old drunk man, and what do you know, another old drunk man. That is a great sign for a good Irish Gathering place! I then saw a table in the back and we grabbed it. After looking at the menu my eyes zoomed in on Hot & Spicy Phoenix Hot Wings!! Hell yes, it was as if the chicken wing Gods were smiling....and later, laughing....at us.

So we ordered a plate, along with our din din choices and when it arrived, oh yum, did it look good. I greedily grabbed the first one, spooned up some blue cheese on my plate and went to town. Only town, only took about 5 seconds before the "Hot & Spicy" description of the dish hit my tongue, roof and throat, and Sweet Jesus on a bike, these little bastards are HOT!! But so damn good!!

As for the rest of my meal, the fish n chips, they were hugely disappointing. The fish and the batter just didn't have any taste to it which was a bummer since F&C is usually a fun bar meal to order. Oh well, the pot roast looked really good and the side of mac n cheese was okay, but in no ways a home run. I think next time I come here, I will order those wings with the sauce on the side so i can monitor to level of third degree burns I get on my mouth :)
author: Stephy S.

description: Happy hour at the phoenix. Last night was the second time here. Love it. The atmosphere is so chill, food is amazing and the drinks are great. Great place to watch the world cup.
author: Patricia P.

description:
It's dangerous IMing with Arnold G. in the morning.  As y'all know, Arnold knows his food.  He chose this morning to continue a conversation we've been having on and off for awhile: brioche french toast or challah french toast?

This is a conversation that's much more dangerous for me than Arnold, since Arnold hasn't had either, but I've had both.  Arnold, in the meantime, is trying to figure out where to be initiated into the deep rich mysteries of eggy-bread French toast heaven.  When I make French toast myself, I always get challah bread.  When I see brioche french toast at a restaurant, I need to get it.  That's my distinction.

So, I had planned to go to Ritual and just get a scone or something quick with a coffee, and then get down to serious reading.  However, after the conversation with Arnold, I was craving some serious food.  Enter Phoenix Bar.  No French Toast, but Belgian Waffles.  While waiting for my waffle, they gave me a couple of slices of soda bread.

A large disc of a waffle with strawberries on top and 3 slices of bacon.  The waffle was okay, nothing special.  But let's talk bacon.  It's unlike any bacon I've had; it might not even be bacon.  Thin slices of fresh pork with slivers of fat clinging to it, salty and fresh.  It looked like the pork was grilled very quickly, so there's a smoky charred flavor.  Dip it in the maple syrup. 

The wait staff is cheery and attentive.  In the forty minutes I was there, my coffee was topped off about three times.  Low key atmosphere...because a lot of times, you just don't want to be at the "it" brunch spot.

So: 3 stars for the waffle
5 stars for the bacon
5 stars for attentive staff
5 stars for not being hype
author: Sooj O.

description:
(I hate to be the 312th review of this place! I woulda much rather been the 311th! Boo!)

Meh. So something about this place annoys me.

But it's an OK hang out spot, I suppose.

Overrated, though.

I remember this yuppie chick I was talking to once and I were out in front and she kept spontaneously cat-puking these little loads of beer vomit behind her on the sidewalk, then would continue regular conversation (as if each consecutive puke DIDN'T just happen).

:Sigh:

I guess that's kinda what I think of when I think of this place. Hrmm...
author: Kai S.

description:
Why am I now just discovering Magners Irish Cider?!?!?  http://www.magnerscider.com/

On a hot balmy night in SF (how does hot and balmy and SF even go together?) this was ass-kicking good and perfect on the palate.

Bottled (as the waitress said "the Irish prefer it bottled over draft," is that true?) chilled and perfect for a hot summer evening.

I had a deadly good time.
author: Jenn A.

description:
The Phoenix was like a breath of fresh (or rather stale) air after a stagnant trip to Medjool that reminded my of just how old I'm getting, because the mere idea of entering a club makes my skin start itching and my left eye start twitching.

Ahhhhhhhh, stepping into The Phoenix was like coming home. I walked in, looked around at my peeps, demanded a PBR from boyfriend and set up camp at a rickety table in the back where I could rest my tootsies as I watched the crowd, none of who wore anything resembling the t-shirt and sport coat ensemble that forces the cynic inside me to rear its ugly head.

According to my hard A-loving buddies, don't order anything other than beer from one, not so friendly female bartender, who was liberal with anything but the booze. A friend gave her a $20 bill for an $11.50 drink order and was bitched out by said bartender who told her "Do you think we're an ATM?" 

The music is chill, the people are chill (other than friend's drunky McBoyfriend who was pouring hot candle wax on his arms and throwing elbows at any random dude every time he walked through the bar) and the atmosphere is chill.

Roomie and I spotted Michael the Yelp Model and accosted him....ok maybe not accosted, but stared for a good 20  minutes before approaching him without sounding like stalkers. As roomie introduced me (for the second time) I almost passed out of delight, as he asked "Sammy? You mean Sammy S?"

I'm somebody! People know me! *leap leap*

Boyfriend just about slapped me (But you know, the nice kind of slapping) after I went on and on about how people on Yelp actually know who I am and how I thought I just loved them and they didn't love me back, and how I always professes my undying gratitude and obsession to Yelp, but receive nothing in return, and how today as my day to shine and.....oh, well you get it. I'm crazy, and Michael S. knows who I am.
author: Sammy S.

description:
If you ever want to shave several years off the end of your life and enter the world of competitive eating, Phoenix's happy hour is a pretty damn good place to start. You can have a french fry eating contest ($1 a plate), an Irish Nacho eating contest ($3 per plate - a potato skin covered in cheese, bacon, sour cream, and green onion), or, like me and my fat fuck coworkers, you can have a buffalo wings eating contest ($4 per plate).

So, I don't know how you guys out there have your buffalo eating contests, but when we rolled, we were aiming for quantity here, not velocity. The wings here are at least twice as meaty as the "wings" from New Yorker's down the street, and they have a pretty decent amount of kick. You get eight wings/drums and a side of the usual accouterments. 

True, gluttony is a sin. True, gorging yourself isn't healthy. And yes, competitive eating is just another symbol of what's wrong with the country today. Nonetheless, I'm proud to report that I dominated the competition, 16 to 10 to 8. That's right bitches, I ate almost as many as my two "competitors", Tramaine Lott and Daniel Dorman did. Not only that, but I got nicely buzzed on the three and four dollar happy hour beers they had there.

The Irish waitresses are all very cute (accents: hot), they have sports on TV that ironic hipsters hate unless it's Albanian velodrome racing,  the drink selection is solid, and again, the Happy Hour is amazing. The only thing I can tell you not to do is say "I just ate so much, I can't possibly get drunk. Let's go have a Long Island Iced Tea drinking competition at the Makeout Room." Because if you say that, you'll probably be following that up with a projectile vomit distance competition.
author: Eric M.

description:
I came in keeping my eyes peeled for Brian Westbrook, the starting running back for the Philadelphia Eagles and the mainstay of my fantasy team. I was sadly disappointed.

No, I didn't expect to see the man himself here; I came to watch the Eagles-Bears game with a friend... who happens to manage the fantasy team I'm going head-to-head with this week. Westbrook was a last-minute scratch from the Eagles' roster, much to my friend's delight, but Phoenix was a great place to watch the game and catch up anyway. 

The service was quick and friendly, despite them being so full that we had to wait for a table. Draft beers (at least a dozen, $5 each) are served in 20oz glasses, so be prepared! The beer went well against the appetizers we ordered--calamari, fries, and wings. The calamari was a bit overcooked and under-flavored, but the wings (spicy!) and particularly the fries (complete with 3 dipping sauces) were very good. 

Parking nearby is a bear, but it's a reasonable walk from 16th/Mission BART so you should be able to fly over with no problem. Just don't take your eye off the ball.

TRIVIA: The phoenix has its origin in ancient Egypt, where it was depicted as stork-like, and is believed to have been based on a flamingo. Flamingos nest in extremely hot areas and build elevated nests that flutter in the breeze like a flame. A symbol of rebirth, the phoenix is found in the mythologies of nearly all of Europe, North Africa, and even loosely in China and Japan.
author: Bill B.

description: Great food and drinks!  The server with the short blond hair is on point!
author: Justin H.

description:
The food was delicious.  Way better than your standard pub-fare.

I got meatloaf topped with irish bacon, and some type of veggies that were gravy covered.  Add a delicious pint, and some fresh cut fries and I was basically in meat heaven.

Just a tad pricey for me, but hey, it would've been cheaper if I stopped on my first pint!
author: Rocco B.

description:
Like many of the random bars in the Mission, this place has a casual atmosphere, generally nice clientele and decently priced drinks. These all apply, but it was also nice coming to a place slightly off-axis from all of the busier bars in the area. 

My drinks were good, I had a great time with friends and even made some new ones. Wonderful! And the bathrooms didn't repulse me, which is always a plus. I might just need to come here for the food now.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Why is this place called the Phoenix?

Who the hell knows.  

But I can hypothesize that it has something to do with the fact that there are quite a few Irishmen with red hair and freckles.

Perhaps the mythical phoenix took fiery red dumps all over the Irish populace and converted most of them to red heads?

Given that I now work for a UK based company I had to prepare.  

I had to prepare for a group of teammates who consider it a "light" evening of drinking if you only have 7 or 8 beers.

And that was told to me by one of my female teammates.  

Who better to whip me in to shape than the always fab Grace K?  I mean, the girl drank Soju in her bottle as a baby so she's gotta have some skills right?

Grace and I hopped into this place after dinner one night and got to work right away.

Long story short...

End of the night, I was shit housed, she was merely housed...and she judged my performance.

Her verdict.  

Indeterminable at this time - repeat as often as necessary.

Not a bad place to hang out.  The giant open window in the front is a cool place to throw a pint back.  

Cheerio.
author: Archie R.

description:
Go for the brunch,  Very friendly cute & flirty bartenders and has that cool "neighborhood feel" What else satisfies the soul while playing hooky from work on a sunny late morning/early afternoon-----A pint with eggs and potatoes.
Oh, and you can bring in your dog.
author: Kia B.

description: The Phoenix is a great bar for those who like to drink, to drink.  Period.  I'd never eat there, and would never recommend a woman to use their bathrooms, but I really enjoy drinking there.
author: Mike H.

description:
I fucking hate this place, yet my restless self is lured here at least once a week by my buddy.  I am curious about why it's still dragging out its menial existence at one of the busiest bar scenes in SF.  Let it die Justin.  You are one of six people still keeping it in business.  

I wanna Kevorkian this place and put something more inspiring here.  Maybe a dimly lit art bar with a dj booth and candles.  No...wait....

Bukowski would love this place with its disenchanted regulars and down and outers.  Shame on me.
author: Xandria S.

description:
This block in the Mission has many good things:  826 Valencia, Paxton Gate, Range, and the Phoenix.

I've always had a good time at the Phoenix.  It's an Irish bar that I can go to wearing heels and not feel like a total asshole.  Very easy to hang out and look at sports on TV whiile loading up the jukebox with your favorite songs.

Bartenders are cool.  When in an Irish bar, order a beer or straight alcohol.  They do a proper pour on a Guinness.

It has the comfort of a pub atmosphere without the grunge, like an Irish bar you would find near your college campus. Sometimes that's exactly what you want.
author: Liz S.

description:
The atmosphere is relaxed, unpretentious, and fun. Last time I was there, I spotted someone that could have been my granny-she looked so sweet, surrounded by family members, but none seemed more delighted by their ale, than Miss Granny G. Mental note: when and if I ever do reach that age I will make sure to frequent pubs like this because if I only have a handful of years left I might as well booze it up w/family and friends.

The music is never annoying or boring, on my visit I heard David Bowie, Radiohead, Erykah Badu, and Johnny Cash. Beers are served cold, cold cold, and food is tasty. I recommend the Irish Potato Nachos (good for 2) and served with creme fraiche and guacamole and a guinness on the side. Yeah I know, not exactly waist friendly food, but it certainly makes for an enjoyable Sunday evening.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
It would only seem fit to take my friend in town from New York to an Irish pub. We started off the trip at one, met at another one after a long day at work for me, even had lunch at one after walking the entire city it seemed.

After a delicious meal at Sunflower, we made the walk to the Phoenix. My only shock was that, "shit! I haven't been here before?"

At first glance, I got a little antsy since it seemed like the cast of Animal House might blow through its doors, but once settled with a drink and seat, I was ok. 

Good people, good vibes, friendly staff...no wonder this Irish girl gravitates naturally towards these spots.
author: Jessica P.

description:
you can listen to Broken Social Scene AND be a sports fan and not feel weird about it!!  this place is an oasis of great game watching, boozing and consorting with the whole spectrum of species the Mish has to offer.  

I've had awesome dates here, seen mind-blowing World Cup games at 8:15 in the morning and escaped the hipster flood from Delores Park on a hot Saturday afternoon.  

The meatloaf is off the chain, too.
author: nick w.

description: This is one of the few Mission bars that is clean enough to the point where you would want to eat in. And the food here is damn good! Always crowded every time I have been in the joint...
author: Jim B.

description:
Yay Phoenix!  Best Pub-Grub in the Mission, possibly the best fish n' chips in town, and easily the best soda bread this side of the Emerald Isle.

And you serve brunch as well!  Admittedly, I thought it was a little weird going to a bar for breakfast, like entering a bar before 3pm for any reason automatically made me an alcoholic, but whatever, I just had coffee.  And hey!  You have good coffee too!  And a great Eggs Benedict on that famous soda bread, with thick and salty Irish bacon and chips (fries) on the side.  Fries for breakfast!?!?  Whatever, they're potatoes.  You know I'd eat fries for breakfast everyday if I could...

Also, this is a cool place to get a mellow drink with friends at (yes, they really are a bar!) if you can score a table in the back, so long as there's not some game on TV that everyone is watching and going crazy over, then it can get loud and boisterous, especially if its the Red Sox or the Celtics or Irish Soccer or something like that.  But hey, if you are into that kind of thing, then Phoenix is the place to go for that, too!
author: Kevin H.

description:
The Phoenix is a great Irish bar where you can:
A:  find your Lucky Charms
B. watch the game 
C. get fluthered on jars
D. chow down on some great mac n' cheese
E.  pick up a fine thing
F. All of the above.
If you answered anything but F,  feel free to use this fine Irish line to express yourself to your bartendress or server.
"Go n-ithe an cat th is go n-ithe an diabhal an cat."
May the cat eat you, and may the cat be eaten by the devil.

For translations or to brush up on your Irish slang, check out: http://www.irishabroad.com/Culture/Slang/irishslang.asp
author: Phil M.

description: Watched the Stanford vs. Oregon game here Saturday night! Wow, what a game! The food was great too for a reasonable price except for the whiskey! Overpriced for what it is. $22 dollars for shot!! wow!! Besides that, everything was great! Good atmosphere and excellent wait service!
author: Jerry K.

description:
Walking up Valencia with a buddy the other day. He checks the crowd and asks me, "What's this? Richmond-In-The-Mission Day?".

While I can't fault imperial pints and potato nachos, once I'm done drinking and snacking here it's time to move on. The bartenders and servers here are the quality in my experience and even though the vibe here is damn near exactly the same as nearby The Liberties or Napper Tandy, the food is better than both of those joints.

I'm just saying, I'm over-stimulated. A fake Oirish Poob just doesn't do it for me. I need a movie night, karaoke, a sweary quiz or some sort of activity where America's Next Top Model and Mystery Science Theatre 3000 are combined to hilarious and sweary effect.

So I'm bored, essentially. And it's not totally The Phoenix's fault.
author: Jeremy W.

description: Cold Smithwick's on tap, best bangers & mash in town, and really nice staff.  Outside of the crowd which is unavoidable on a Friday night in this part of town, a great place to hang out with your friends.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I came here on Saturday night with friends and was actually very surprised by the food there.  I got a black and blue burger and it wasn't bad for pub food.  I would recommend getting the taytos though, the home style potato chips they serve, as they were very tasty and greasy.  

The decor is nothing to write home to mommy about, but it's an Irish pub, so can't really expect much past the typical TVs, mirrors, and tacky art.  

I would definitely return here for a few beers, before I hit up Osha Thai next door, which I just discovered!
author: James C.

description:
Let me count the ways that coming to the Phoenix was both entertaining and strange:

1) It's an Irish pub in the heart of hipster heaven
2) There weren't any real Irish people here (unlike my neighborhood pubs which are full of the real deal)
3) The night we came, there were a strange amount of Marina-like folk hanging out at the bar... did they really venture all the way to the Mission to come here?
4) A guy with a guitar found his way inside and started serenading a table of extremely drunk men with his Spanish songs
5) The above-mentioned group had 2 tables, both of which were entirely full of Corona bottles, one of which fell and shattered on the ground right behind me
6) The bathroom smelled disgusting. And they ran out of paper towels.
7) A server constantly came around and made sure we had enough to drink- huge perk since it was nearly impossible to get to the bar
8) The music rotated between Coldplay, U2 and other notable bands from the other side of the English Channel

I probably wouldn't come here again out of choice, but there's definitely nothing wrong with it. It's a nice, chill bar that feels like a breath of Blarney Stone air in the Mission.
author: Jared S.

description: I give 5 stars to the Phoenix for one reason. Jess the day bartender/manager is an excellent hostess. She does a great job, makes the place a nice place to hang at lunch, - otherwise it's a decent pub with food that ranges from pretty good to not so great.
author: chris n.

description:
The Phoenix is loud at night and the service kind of sucks but for some reason I really like the place. The Shepherd's Pie and Pork Tenderloin sandwich are spot on, the beer selection is cool with me, and I do like that the girls working the bar are actually Irish (some of them at least).

I think the best part of the Phoenix is that there is a lot space so you're not all jammed up with the crew of lesbians having an Easter shouting party.
author: Rob D.

description:
I was taken here for a belated birthday celebration and I was pleasantly surprised by how much fun I had .  I mean when I walked in, the place was sparsely populated with the standard Mission hipster crowd, and they had some loud, obnoxious, honky tonk music playing overhead.  I was like uh-oh.  But then I looked at the menu and noticed a wide array of tasty-sounding food items and beer options and decided not to judge this place too quickly.  We ordered the potato nachos (good but too cheesy for my liking) and the fish and chips (quite tasty).  My friend also told me that they serve a pretty good breakfast as well during the day.

After a while, the music selection changed for the better and became more diverse, the place filled up, we ran into some friends, and the beers began to work their magic.  Our group was asked to participate in a movie naming contest by some random bar patron named Dan and although he was slightly skeevy, that type of communal interaction is always the hallmark sign of a good watering hole in my opinion.   If you're curious, the contest was to name the most visually stunning movie that you've ever seen.

Answers from our table (that I can remember):
1.  Star Wars
2.  Flight of the Navigator
3.  Hero
4.  Monsoon Wedding
5.  Wizard of Oz
6.  Being John Malcovich
7.  Big Fish
8.  Pan's Labyrinth
author: LaSha G.

description:
surprisingly good food. 

awesome copper bar counter.

flat screens everywhere. 

bartender that will drink some random whisk(e)y with you? 

nice
author: Euge L.

description: Mm Irish Nachos and onions rings with some Guinness. And my happy hour bill is only $10 for all of that? Yes please!
author: Analisa S.

description:
Totally overpriced.

Some of the old-time bartenders are not very kind to you if you're not an alcoholic that goes there everyday. I'm not an alcoholic and that is not my choice of bar.

The second to the last time I was there was the first time I went actually being 21. Before that, it was almost a year since I was there. There was a book reading of Alexander Cockburn and my friends wanted to go to the Phoenix and I didn't. There was only two of us out of six that wanted to go somewhere else, so we lost and went. 

The bartenders that were there before I turned 21 were well aware that I was under 21 when I used to go more frequently. The only reason they would serve me drinks because I would go with a few of their alcoholic customers that pracically keep the place running. Those alcoholic customers were now out of my life and they were well aware of that.
 
So I went with my new friends that are more suitable for my safety. I was still new at ordering drinks from any bar and I was still unsure what is a cool way to act ad not make it obvious that you don't have drink ordering experience. But  did went and got an old-timer bartender that did a few of my drinks when I was under 21 (and she was well aware of that).

Here is our conversation:

Me: I'll like a margarita.

Her: ID?

Me: (take it out and give it to her)

Her: (doesn't even look at the ID) Last time you were here you were under 21.

Me: That's correct. It was almost a year ago and I had something called a "birthday" during that time. If you look at my ID, you'll see that I am 21 now.

Her: (looks at the ID, rolls her eyes, and goes make the drink)

Me: (gets the drink and turn to make a comment) It's funny how that time almost a year ago you were well aware I was under 21...and yet, you still made my drinks.

Her: (face of furry and pretends she doesn't hear me)

Me: (don't tip)

The other bartenders were normally nice and I would tip them the rest of the night. I have nothing against this bartender, but she obviously has something against me. But I wont take it personally...she's only a bartender. I was perfectly legally there that night and I was not being obnoxious, so it would have been a waste of time for her to start a fuss and not serve me.

I went one more time after this incident and I don't think she was there. But who cares. This is not my bar of choice, but if friends want to come here, I'll go.

THe drinks are ok to go an get one or two if you're buying, but not when youre budgeting. Don't expect much from the service since they do take forever with the drinks  and food. I do recommend going to order your drinks from the bar than from the waitresses. It's quicker. The food is not worth the money.
author: Daisy A.

description:
Man, if you put "Irish" in front of anything, it makes it better. 

Think about it.  

irish coffee != normal coffee

Ok, that's the only one I can think of right now.

BUT! The Phoenix has Irish Nachos, which are like normal nachos, but made with potatoes instead of tortilla chips. So like, the best meal ever.

irish pub != normal pub
author: Maia B.

description:
Cool bar. Awful service.
Went in with a group of friends last Friday night and was excited to get seats at the bar! Got our first drinks pretty quickly but that was it. The bartender was too into fixing her lip gloss and checking her iPhone to be bothered with patrons. We sat there staring at her with our empty glasses on the bar and finally I just asked for another drink. 
I can't imagine how much business they lost that night because of the lack of service. Hopefully it isn't always that bad!
author: Kathleen B.

description:
Mhh, Irish food and drinks - although the bacon that came with the breakfast grossed me out a bit. Guess all that dry American stuff has killed my taste for the good stuff.

Perfect for a brunch after a night out, but also for a night out itself.
author: Roland A.

description:
My 5 star review is dedicated to the potato nachos.

Holy Crap they are good.

Now, if only we could have a beer, watch the game, and not run the risk of being nearly run over by a not-very-queer-friendly-dude on the way out, we might actually go back.  But alas, my one potato nacho experience, although nearly orgasmic in my nacho-needing mouth, was not good enough for me to return.  A crying shame.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I knew this place was legit when our server started talking with an Irish accent. Whether real or phony, it brought a certain je-ne-sais-quoi authenticity to the place.

Their bar snacks were like Irish/Mexican fusion. And in my opinion, they pulled it off nicely. We were going to be boring and get the calamari but our server informed us that they were all out so we opted for the Irish Nachos: roasted potato wedges smothered in black beans, guacamole, cilantro and creme fraiche. We wolfed that ish down in no time. The hot wings also fared well. The wings maintained their crispness even after it was tossed in the buffalo sauce. If there's one thing I hate, it's soggy buffalo wings!

Loved the retro Guinness poster that adorned the wall, saying "My Goodness, My Guinness" as well as the other sort of kitschy Irish pub decor. I was into it!
author: Monica N.

description:
This is a weird ass place. I've been there twice now, once just for drinking and once just for eating, and each time I kind of felt like I was in the twilight zone. The crowd here is neither Mission, Marina, nor bridge and tunnel. It's like all the SF guide books for out of towners must point to the Phoenix as the place to go. If you walk in on a crowded Saturday night you feel more like you're in Philadelphia than San Francisco. I know others feel the same way, its just a weird phenomenon.

As for the food...I think its just so so. I had the claim chowder and it tasted more like rosemary and potato soup than anything resembling clams. My friend got a corned beef sandwich and it was literally just like two small chunks or corn beef on bread. Boring. 

The upside about this place for me is that when you're feeling really sick of all the local dives and annoying hipsters its a good refuge...
author: Jennifer C.

description: Awesome soda bread and bloody Mary's. A little spotty in the service front.
author: Michelle K.

description:
3.5 stars

My first impression of the Phoenix was quite positive, but repeat visits proved to be less satisfying.  The food and service are hit and miss, and the bar can get quite crowded at times.  Phoenix does have Leffe on tap, for which it is receives the extra .5 stars.  Despite my mixed feelings about this establishment, I'm sure I'll be coming back.
author: Grace W.

description: great food, people, staff and music. the only thing was that it's kind of small, so everyone was packed. it was kind of overwhelming how many people were in there and i felt it was violating some kind of capacity code. overall though, great experience and glad my friend took me there.
author: Cecily B.

description:
Who would have thunk and Irish bar could have such good food?  I love coming here for brunch, the Irish breakfasts are yummy.  You must come with an appettite because the portions are pretty big.  The meals are not cheap but not super expensive, though your bill can get a little pricey if you're ordering Irish coffees or mimosas with breakfast, I think there about $8 or so.  Usually it's not very crowded for brunch or lunch, it's a nicely kept secret.  I don't know why but rainy days make me want to stay here all day drinking Irish coffees.

I've been here in the evening as well and their kitchen is open late so I ordered the fish tacos.  Not bad.  Certain appetizers are also half off during happy hour so I've munched on a lot of their foods.  Booze plus food keeps me happy so I like coming here.
author: P D.

description: This is my new fave neighborhood place. It's comfy, you can chat, it has an inventive menu, good beers on tap, i.e. Boddington's. Lots of condiments.  I likey.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I was looking for some grog to wet my whistle and some vittles to fill my belly after refreshing my stock of eyepatches, snuff, rope and mops from the pirate supply at 826 Valencia and found exactly what I needed across the street at the Phoenix.

They must run a tight ship here since we had our waitress at our table at once after every done dish, every dropped fork, every 'where's the chipotle tabasco bottle' (yes!  tabasco varietals rule), all during the World Cup-- Mexico had just won their match against Iran, so you can imagine the neighborhood joy and celebration.  By the way, the many TVs in every area of the place makes it a great afternoon sports pub.  The walls are covered with your typical Irish kitsch that makes you think, 'Hey, why don't I have a shot of Tullamore Dew and a pint of Guinness to ease it down?'

So they forgot to bring me my side of rashers... chances are, you will turn out with more than you thought or wished you had ordered.  Thank you for attempting to save me from death by oh so deliciously salty indulgence, wench.  (I still haven't re-repressed my inner pirate.)   We had a hefty  Irish Breakfast and thick dark beer.  I have vowed to return again and taste their shepherd's pie.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
Who doesn't love a good Irish pub?  I went here late, late, late and grabbed a post-wedding beer with some friends. At first I thought, "yeah this is cool, but nothing mindblowing".
Then I had some scotch.

This place is now going down in Stephanie history as: "The Bar Where I Tried Scotch For The First Time". 

Fun spot for a chill evening, throwing back the drinks with your pals. Attentive bartenders and a laid-back crowd which was nice for a change. I haven't tried their food, but I'm definitely going back when I move back into the city.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
this place is awesome!! their happy hour is by far one of the greatest selection of foods i've ever had. the drinks are kinda whatevers.

we got 2 orders of wings, onion rings, curry fries, artichoke dip, and i wanna say we got more but i dont remember. all the food was pretty good. wings were kinda average, nothing special. but at least they werent packaged kind. the curry fries were AMAZING. loved every bite of it. onion rings were ok as well. their soda bread is also very tasty. its sweet, soft and doesnt fall apart.

atmosphere is great in here. love it for giants games and the waitresses are all very friendly and deserve huge tips for being so accommodating and friendlty
author: edward k.

description:
As we walked up to this place, I thought "Dear lord, I didn't bring my side-arm with me tonight." It just didn't look all that friendly. Yeah yeah yeah...don't judge a book by it's cover. Whatever.

We get inside - WHOA! Completely not what I was expecting. It's cute...like wood-panels and funky photos and wall hangings and people laughing and chatting and enjoying themselves. WOW!

We got basic drinks...pretty decent. They poor like a mad-man (or woman) and I remember taking my first sip and saying "Looks like I'm getting drunk tonight!" The people were friendly, the place was awesome, the $1 garlic fries were amazing. ONE DOLLAR! WHAT?!

I didn't try any of the other food, so can't rate that. But it's definitely a place that would be nice to hang out after work for a get-together with friends. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Friendly attractive bartenders, delicious food, and quenching drinks (including Magners)

The table service I had there was only ok, but at the bar they take care of you.

The Phoenix is an Irish Pub that manages to stand out to me because of the quality of food and bartender.  A great way to differentiate.
author: laura g.

description: It's a shame because this place has a nice vibe that makes you want to hang out for a few hours. It doesn't have a wheelchair accessible bathroom. It's accessible to get in the door, but who wants to drink at a bar with no bathroom? Not me. Good place to stop through and have a beer. Thankfully, it's on Valencia which is full of other awesome bars that you can settle into and leave your worries behind.
author: Shannon M.

description:
I can't put my finger on the clientle, where do they come from? 

Are there really that many normal people live between 16th and 24th street?  Where are all the tights as pants, the bike riding hipsters, where are all the people who make the mission so fun?

Not here. 

Ugghh.. An Irish bar, for those of you who need to drink without adventure or attitude.  Yes, the drinks are alcoholic and wet but are they fun?  No.

Boring old Guinness posters.  Boring bar scene.  Boring people.  

Snoozefest. 

Note: Haven't had a brunch here so I can't rate their boring food.
author: Krissy M.

description: I like this place. Maybe it's the comfortable vibe inside, maybe it's the decent prices for food they offer, maybe it's the extensive beer menu, maybe it's the personable service, maybe it's the group of people I have brought with me to this pub, maybe it's the location, maybe I need to go here tonight.
author: Ashlee F.

description:
My husband and I thought, great, a comfortable place to eat dinner, watch some baseball, and drink some decent beer.   We had a pleasant enough experience the first time, although one cannot deny that this is a marina "transplant" bar.  

However, on a second outing to the Phoenix for a beer, dinner, and Giants game, we were surprised that both TV screens were playing the red sox/yankees game. I don't care, they may be two more skilled teams, in a superior league, playing a more interesting game, but it is unacceptable that when we asked them to switch ONE of the two tvs to the Giants game, we were flat out denied by the bartender, who had the nerve to tell us that we would need to go somewhere else to watch the game.

This is the type of BS that makes SF look like the lame sports town that it probably is.  Phoenix made me embarassed to be a bay area native.
author: Marie K.

description:
Went the morning of the super bowl and had brunch. They had bowling and basketball on tv, thank god. Irish bread- YUM! They do Irish big breakfast, little breakfast and delicious permutations of brunch classics. Irish bacon comes on everything, even the waffles so its all good.

Bloody marys with lots of veg served by charming, not sober waitresses with the cute irish accents. How can you go wrong?
author: Krismet C.

description:
Good cider on tap and free soda bread!!!!

Truly yummy on both accounts. If that hasn't already wet your whistle (some people aren't into hard cider and/ or bread) then let the full menu of mostly meaty treats (sorry my veggie and vegan friends there isn't much on the menu except salads and a few other things) entice you. YOU'VE ALREADY EATEN- THEN  DRINK! And drink you shall. The Phoenix offers a wide selection of beers and spirits.
author: Christie A.

description:
Irish accents + pints of Guinness + chill atmosphere + nice waitresses = a perfect bar. The Phoenix is great because, unlike many other SF restaurants/bars, it is not trying to be overly hip.  Thank the f'in Lord.  

Great place to meet up with friends to share a pint.  The Shepard's Pie is pretty good too if you're hungry.
author: Julianne H.

description:
Great bar here. They've created quite a reputation in SOMA. I like the drinks here and the bartenders are really friendly. Their customers, for the most part, are solid. 

The only issue going forward with this place (i think it plague's every bar and nightclub) is lack of focus on reputation building. 
There're no proprietary products that they offer. They don't brew their own beer, they don't make unique kobe burgers, they don't sing a tune when you tip them, etc.. So at the end of the day all you get is just a bar with a restaurant menu that serves American bar food.

Call me crazy but I'd probably not put 8 different burgers, 7 different meat & potato entrees and 10 different sandwiches on the menu. 

Why not create & hype up one high quality entree that people in SOMA start to rave about?
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: Awesome food, friendly staff, good crowd, great atmosphere, wise quotes on the walls, and of course alcohol (especially the beers they have on tap). Been here on numerous occasions and not once have I experienced a letdown. Come here for their happy hour for great deals. Cool spot that is worth your patronage.
author: Alvin T.

description:
It looks and feels like a classic Irish pub always filled with people and lively conversation.  They have a great happy hour and the food is actually pretty good. 

My faves are the fish and chips and the goat cheese  salad with apples and caramelized walnuts -- nothing too original or creative, but reliable and well-made classics.  Actually, that last sentence just summed up how I feel about the Phoenix.
author: Sid D.

description:
This is a great, laid back place to sit and drink for hours while friends come and go.  It's the perfect Zeitgeist alternative for when it's too darn cold outside to spend any amount of time in the beer garden.

They've got a good beer selection and surprisingly delicious and fresh bar food.  The fish taco come with piles of fresh lettuce and avocado, the "nachos" are made with potatoes, and the quesedilla's are fantastic!   I also like the burgers, the sauteed spinach and the fries.

It's a great cozy neighborhood bar with above average bar food.  If you snag a booth you've got it made.
author: Shayna N.

description: Came here to watch opening night football and I was impressed.  They have a good draft beer selection including a few great IPAs, which had me sold.  The sliders were DELICIOUS, as were the chicken fingers and fries.  Good Happy Hour deals. I'd definitely come back, esp for a game as they had lots of TV's.
author: Genevieve S.

description:
Yum Phoenix Wings!
Other than that, they have a really decent selection of beers and it's just a great watering hole, overall. Service is a little dodgy at times and it definitely gets really crowded, but for a pub, it's alright by me.
author: Erin P.

description:
Excellent fish & chips. Really excellent Irish soda bread. Huge, strong cocktails for under $10. Bartenders with real Irish accents.

Cool spot for a laid back night out.
author: Deb I.

description:
This place is pretty awesome. 

The irish nachos are a must get. I had the charboiled chipotle sandwich and it wasn't all that tasty... but really... was I ever there to eat? 

nope...

Just go, grab some beers, and enjoy!!! It's a nice pubby feel, the server, I don't know her name but she's got a great memory and a nice accent.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
They have really great bar food here, this is one of my favorite spots to grab a quick dinner,the corn beef sand which is heaven as far as I'm concerned, and the Shepard's pie is god as well, lot's of good flavor and texture., not all watery and gross drinks aren't to pricey, good selection of beer, most of the time the atmosphere is good, and you can find a table.  Although can be quite crowded during major sporting events. Over all good place for food, fun and drink.
I've heard they've got really good blood mary's I'll give an update when I make it to brunch.
author: JIll H.

description:
19th Street Ding: Hog & Rocks, The Phoenix
Two establishments blocks away with wing quality miles apart.

Hog & Rocks (http://www.hogandrocks.com/) is "legit." The wings were strong across the board. Their strong point was their kick. It was the best kick I have had in SF. It wasn't a make-you-drool burn, but a lingering spice that never breached the comfortable level. The flavor of the wing sauce gets points for originality. It had a sweet touch but never strayed from the wing flavor. Personally, I am not big on the sweet sense, but the flavor was still good. And Kevin Youkilis apparently signed off on it which is cool. The crisp was the weakest part of the order. It wasn't completely missing, but they could have been fried longer. The crisp layer was thin. Ahhh, the dipping sauce was actually the weak spot. It was some house dip which had a garden veggie feel. It was good for the carrots and celery, but it was sweet, which didn't go well with wings that had a sweet touch. Next time I will request bleu cheese and then I think this order gets ridiculously good. The vibe of the place was cool and the vibe is upscale. The order was on the small side with 8. The wing size was small, which I love, and the sauce was poured a little too liberally, but nothing agregious (see Giordano Bros.)
Overall: A-

The Phoenix (http://www.phoenixirishbar.com/) order is amateur. They came breaded without the option to get regular. They were huge footballs. The sauce had no kick and was typical wing sauce. Probably the cheapest bulk box they could get at Restaurant Depot. The bleu cheese was standard. Cool bar vibe but understaffed.
Overall: C

itsawingding.blogspot.com
author: Christopher R.

description:
pretty damn good!

Irish nachos (aka cheese potatoes) were yummy

GREAT wings

Cajun Chicken sandwich rocked.

Waitress (blond cute thing) rocked too...
author: Matt V.

description:
We: A group of seven desiring a quiet table and beer

You: A quiet bar with plenty of free tables large enough for eight, and a decent range of beer on tap.

This could be the start of a beautiful relationship.
author: Glen M.

description:
20oz Imperial Pints.  That's like buy 2, get one free, ALL THE TIME!!

Holy Shit!

This place feels like the sort of joint that Irish ex-pats come to to unwind.  It's real.  It's not cheesy, it's not kitchy, it's right.

The food is great, I had one of the best brunch's ever here a few weeks ago.  I had the irish fried steak and eggs...  drool.  They pulled the Irish bacon and onion appetizer from the menu for some reason, and I wish it would be brought back.  It was divine.

The Phoenix does all right by me.
author: Tony A.

description: This place used to be great.  I went there all the time.  It started to go down hill when they stopped carrying my favorite beer about a year ago.  I still liked the food, so I kept going anyway.  Over time I found other places to go for happy hour, places that had my beer.  I had not gone back for almost a year,  When I did, I was shocked.  I ordered one of my favorites there, the meatloaf.  It came out at about 1/2 the serving it used to be.  I kid you not, a serving of meatloaf that is thinner than the new iphone.  Not to mention, it was burned.  That's right burned.  Thinner than a burger, and burned.  I ate this while sipping a $6 happy hour beer. $6?  It is clear that they have made changes to save money.  The servings have suffered.  They have increased their prices, and the beer selection has suffered and gone up in price too.  I sent a complaint to them via facebook.  Not even an apology for serving burned food that I even went so far as to send a picture of.  They are used to having people come in, so they don't care if everyone is satisfied.  Well, they lost my business.
author: Pamela R.

description:
Two words:  Happy Hour.

This place has fantastic fish tacos for $3 during Happy hour.  Add that to the $3 garlic fries... Nummers!!   And, all big enough to share (or not).

Stay away from the Irish Nachos:  potato wedges covered with greasy cheese and sour cream.  If you do get them, eat them FAST because otherwise they solidify into a weird dairy/potato pile.  

We like going here to watch all the sports on TV, while sitting at the bar, and gorging ourselves for Happy Hour prices.     (4-7PM)
author: Val K.

description:
This is my default pint drinking venue. What I look for in such places are three things 1) actual PINTS of decent beer 2)ability to consistently get a seat for me and a few friends but still have the place feel like it has a critical mass 3) wood-paneled irish bar goodness.

Anecdote: Halloween, some unfortunate revelers came into the bar dressed in british colonial millitary garb carrying the union jack. The bar literally went dead silent. As a matter of practice, it is a bad and often dangerous idea to do anything too british in an irish bar . . . let alone walk in waiving the goddamn union jack. Because we are in happily peaceful SF someone pulled the kids aside and explained. Flag was lowered, inflamed irish tempers were soothed by another great pint.

I've never eaten here (i think I had fries once, but do not recall the details of that evening) so this is based on many a mid-sunday afternoon beer and many a late evening last stop, or first stop.
author: Jen A.

description: This is that style of bar you'll be able to locate in any country around the world. They have good food, many TV's for watching games, but sometimes there is too many people to get a seat. Friendly staff and pretty good beer selection. If you want to watch some sports, check this place out!
author: Caitlin F.

description: Nice little place in the mission area we came across during a daylight crawl. Sat at the table with the open window so got alot of the street vibe as well as the chill atmosphere going on inside. Friendly staff. Got talked into their dinner specials-that's why the 3 stars. Very average food. Of course it is a "pub" of sorts, so I wasn't expecting much. Still, I'd come back.
author: Mark W.

description:
One steamy afternoon in the Mission, I hear "Radio Clash" coming from an Irish pub I'd always ignored.  My mate, much more visually stimulated, can't look away from the sign saying "fish and chips".  We both wander in, dreamlike.

The bartender says they have cider, and would we like it draught or bottle.  My gods.  A Mission bar that not only treats cider a notch or two above wine cooler, but offers a rather good brand ON TAP.

The fish and chips are excellent.  Amazing, actually.

Two hours later, my mate and I wander out, cider-buzzed and belly-full, heading west into a smoldering sunset, wondering when we'll wake up.
author: Naomi M.

description:
The garlic fries were pretty cheap - $2.50 for a big plate, but you know what? They were all small bits and odds and ends. It's like I got the bottom of the frozen bag. Maybe I was just unlucky, but it's no fun trying to dip a french fry as small as my fingernail into a globule or ketchup.

And what was that dipping sauce? Mayonnaise, pure mayonnaise with maybe a dried oregano flake in it.

Ok, so maybe food isn't what the Phoenix is all about. Yea, it was cool to be able to remotely carry on a conversation with friends late on a Sat. night on Valencia St. without having to scream over drunken hordes. Ok. I'll go back, but I won't order the fries!
author: maureen f.

description: Good Irish fate but its very pubby which is something we don't love. Shepard pie was great but came out super hot.
author: Dan Q.

description: I had the lamb shank with mashers and veggies and it was okay. The meat should have been hotter but I've been here before and Ive tried the mac and cheese, sheppard's pie and fish and chips and in general their food is very good. I'll keep coming back for more as they have tons of TVs to watch FOOTBALL! =)
author: Genaro R.

description:
This is a great bar, Irish or no, in the mission.  Usually sports a good mix of hip peeps and alcohol paramours.

Everything I've tried on the menu is super tasty which makes this place a suitable destination just about any time of the day for sports, a meal, or a couple of pints with some friends.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Finally! A great Irish pub.  And yes, I agree with Justine that there ARE cute boys here!  I'm off the market, but if I weren't, I would recommend skipping out on the Bro-rina and come to Phoenix.

The bartenders are the rare breed of "chill girls" in this city, they have Stella on tap which make me a very happy lady, and it's always a rockin time when we get the boys n girls together here.
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
The Mission is not my usual neighborhood but when I am there and want to grab a drink and a bite, I usally come here.  Went to the bar to watch the game on a Thursday night with a buddy.  Got there during happy hour and basically ordered everything on the happy hour menu!  The wait for the food was a little on the long side, but the place was full so maybe it's to be expected.  The fish tacos were great and so was the sliders.  The Irish nachos were fantastic and you can't beat the happy hour prices.  The prices do go up quite a bit after happy hour.  If you have to order from the regular menu, I'd go with the shepards pie.

It's a cool place to watch a game - they have plenty of TVs, expecially in the back, so every seat is pretty decent.  I'm a beer guy, so I can't comment on the quality of mixed drinks.  I sometimes wish they had more servers because things can get hectic, expecially during dinner time, but the servers are friendly and helpful when you get their attention.

So if you are bumming around the Mission and looking for some pub grub, a drink and maybe a little TV viewing, this may be the spot for you.
author: Ed W.

description:
The space is brilliant, the beers are cold, and the menu is magnificent but Phoenix failed to deliver.  I'm not sure if it was just the afternoon rush, but it was slow slow slow.  The shepherd's pies my friends ordered were rich and flavorful- some of the best I've had.  The waitress had a little spilling problem, we saw her spill on three different people then she knocked a beer over on our table too.
